metadata.title: How to use AI on the Higgs boson. The God particle is still full of… | by Ari Joury, PhD | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: How to use AI on the Higgs boson
metadata.description: Particle physicists at CERN discovered the Higgs boson in 2012. Now, the quest is to learn more about its properties. AI plays a crucial role in this. It’s Sunday. You and I are taking a walk in the…

all_paragraphs: Particle physicists at CERN discovered the Higgs boson in 2012. Now, the quest is to learn more about its properties. AI plays a crucial role in this.
It’s Sunday. You and I are taking a walk in the park. Our dog Pluto is bouncing around us, eager to play. You throw a stick for it to catch.
Then you turn towards me. ‘You used to work on the Higgs boson, right?’
‘Yep! That was four years after its discovery though.’
‘What was left to do if it was already discovered?’

‘Well, we know now that the Higgs boson exists. But a lot of its properties are still unknown. I and my colleagues were working on strategies of how to find out whether a Higgs boson could decay into Dark Matter inside a particle collider.’
‘So, like, the Higgs boson breaks and the remnants are Dark Matter?’
AI could shine a light on the mysteries of the Higgs boson

‘That’s the theory, yes. We don’t know for sure whether that really happens. But it’s worth investigating. That’s why I and my colleagues thought about how one could detect these decays — if they exist. And we found that Artificial Intelligence was the best way to do that.’
‘For that you need to understand what kind of problems we’re addressing in the first place.

‘At CERN, particle detectors capture what happens when two particles collide at very high energies. Each type of particle — for example, a quark or a Higgs boson — leaves a characteristic trace in a particle detector. If we put together the traces, one can reconstruct the processes that took place during a collision of two particles.’
‘So you use AI to find out which processes took place?’
‘Not so fast! Let me explain.

‘In some collisions, a Higgs boson is produced. But a Higgs boson has a rather short lifetime, so it quickly decays to other particles. These could be quarks or other bosons, or maybe Dark Matter particles. The latter we call signal events — collisions where Dark Matter is among the resulting particles.
‘Of course we could simply search for the signal among the many processes that the detector registers — we’re talking about half a billion collisions happening each second.

‘The problem is that there are events that look really similar to the signal. But in reality they’re different processes. These we call background events. And we don’t want those to skew our data. So our task was to teach the detector to distinguish the signal from the background.’
‘And how did AI come into play there?’
‘Without AI, we would just look at different properties of the signal, and then cut the dataset where it’s pretty unlikely to find any.

‘For example, one could use the number of quarks that get emitted as a by-product of the decay of the Higgs boson to Dark Matter. In addition to the Dark Matter particles, we might expect two quarks, based on the underlying physics of the process. Sometimes there may be one quark more, sometimes one less. There can be statistical variations.

‘So in this example, we could cut away collisions from our dataset in which we find no quarks, or more than three. We can be pretty confident that they’re no signal events. This way we’ve improved our dataset because it contains a little less background than before.’
‘Is this where AI comes in?’

‘Yes, exactly. The smart thing is that we can make an AI algorithm learn the properties of a signal event. That makes our job a lot easier because it means that we don’t necessarily need to know much about the underlying physics.’
‘You’re being lazy — not studying the underlying physics!’
‘Okay then. And how does the AI learn what is signal and what is background?’

‘There are many different ways. In our case, we used really simple algorithms which are called decision trees. The basic principle is that you first train the algorithm with a fake dataset. This dataset comes from a computer simulation and only contains events which are already correctly labeled as signal or background.
‘The decision tree applies random cuts to the training set and then checks how well it has separated the signal from the background. Then it re-iterates until it has found the best cuts.’
‘But why can’t you do that manually?’

‘We were doing that manually — but it requires a lot of knowledge about the underlying process or else it will take a very long time. Also, it quickly gets complicated because the properties of the signal often depend on one another.

‘For example, two quarks that are emitted in a signal collision might have a certain distance from another. But there might be other signal events where three quarks are involved. In this case, the distances among the three might be different than in the case with two quarks. So we can’t just cut for one distance among quarks. Decision trees are good for taking these kind of dependencies into account.’
‘So in a way the machine knows more than you!’
‘True! That helps us uncover the properties of the Higgs boson.’
You throw the stick for Pluto again.
‘How does that help you with the Higgs?’
‘With AI, we can produce really good datasets which contain lots of signal and few background events. In our case, the signal events are collisions after which a Higgs boson decays to Dark Matter.
‘Now, all we need to do is count the number of signal events that we find. If we find a certain amount, we can say that we have discovered decays of a Higgs boson to Dark Matter particles!’
‘Nope. At least — not yet. Our paper is just one of many steps towards such a discovery. Research takes time!’
The future of the Higgs boson remains exciting
‘It will be interesting to see whether you will discover it! Or whether those decays don’t even exist.’
‘I sure will… Actually, I thought that AI was really hard to understand. But now it doesn’t seem too crazy.’

‘To be fair, we used one of the simplest AI tools that exist. These days, scientists often use more sophisticated algorithms, including supervised deep learning and GANs. But we can talk about those another day if you want.’
‘I’d love to!’ you exclaim as you try to wiggle the stick out of our dog’s mouth. ‘Come on Pluto, we’re going back home!’
